title: For how many weeks will Adam Grant's "Think Again" be on the New York Times Best Sellers list for Combined Print & E-Book Nonfiction between 21 February 2021 and 11 July 2021?
preds: Week 14 showing for week ending 11 July.  But we’re only at the beginning of the week, so it has to stay on the list until the end of the week, and it’s only 14th out of 15
At 14 weeks on the list as on 7/2/21.  I was way off on my initial forecast, so I feel like this is kinda cheating a bit.
Wow, I totally underestimated the likelihood of a reappearance. Now I'll be up all night debating if my logic was wrong or if this was an observation of a low probability event occurring.
Was I just straight-out wrong? Or did something unlikely happen? https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1287385

Just looked into a proxy; Currently ranked 334th overall for soft copy and 8,472nd overall for hardback (1), I would assume NYT combines these into a single sales figure. 1. https://www.amazon.com.au/Think-Again-Power-Knowing-What/dp/0753553899/ref=tmm_pap_swatch_0?_encoding=UTF8&qid=&sr=
1 week to go, moving from 80 to 91%
With just 1 week to go, 13 weeks would most likely be the final tally.
Updating prior rationale from https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1289082 with July 4 data
Just one shot left to get that 14th listing.

Post-mortem errors: (1) Put too much emphasis on time passing, (2) ignored how noisy the trend downward was, (3) used "Noise" by Kahneman as a proxy, (4) ignored intuitive feeling of what 100% truly feels like, (5) discarded Bayesian thought at last minute. . . .
@slapthepancake has done on great job of covering this question
With 2 weeks remaining and Summer upon us, it seems quite unlikely that the book will reenter the list.

Two more weeks to go, at 13 weeks on the list. It's been off the list the last 5/6 so if you have independence that implies a 25/36 chance of no more appearance, which is 69.4%. Upping to 80% to account for correlation.
Updating prior rationale from https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1289082 with June 27 data
Noise by Kahneman is out, which is a worrying sign for Think Again. I'm still not sure how summer colleges will affect sales. Then thinking again, it could all be noise.

EDIT:
Two more thrilling weeks to go, and still stuck at 13 weeks. Only four of 15 titles on the week through 27 June 2021 list have been there for more than 10 weeks:
#2 The body keeps the score (42 weeks)
#5 Greenlights (34 weeks)
#7 Untamed (66 weeks)
#9 Caste (45 weeks) The implications of this is twofold:
/the competition for prominent placings is very tough at the moment, probably amid a host of new releases every week, which cannibalize each other's sales
/the group of best-selling titles appears to be sharply divided into two very defined groups:
 (i) titles which are perceived as "interesting" AND "fresh" in the market
 (ii) titles which are much bespoken and have a track record of attracting an ever larger readership, a phenomenon I'd desribe as "ultra-long appearance on the list"
"Think Again!" by Adam Grant doesn't seem to belong to any of the groups at the moment. The only factor of uncertainty for the remaining time to go:
Will there be a cheaper paperback edition in time for this question, a decision likely made by the editors who are monitoring the sales?
The effect of a regular paperback edition, which is obviously available only outside the U.S. can be very different
If available by beginning of July, the paperback will certainly drive up sales in the short-term, could lead to a re-listing of "Think Again!" and would resolve this question on the bin "Between 14 and 18".
If hardcover+ebook varieties remain the sole forms of publication, future readers could abstain from buying the title as a hardcover for a while in the expectation of the much cheaper paperback. The question will likely resolve on bin three "Between 9 and 13" without any further appearance on the best-selling list.
Updating prior rationale from https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1289082 with June 20 data
Adjustment for the passage of time.
Only 4 weeks left.  1 additional week needed to tip the bin.  But not been there for the last 2 weeks.  So feels quite unlikely.
eliminating the lingering 1% in my 4-8 bucket
Ironically, it could be "Noise" by Daniel Kahneman et al. which continues to take away a spot on the list from "Think Again!"...

Now that the June 13 list is out we can eliminate the 18+ bucket since there's only 4 more lists. Lists are dated as the coming Sunday weirdly enough, so the list released on today (June 8) is dated June 13th. So we'll have 4 more for June 20, June 27, July 4, and the July 11 list to close the question. I don't know how to work the NYT APIs and the only data sets I've seen list the top 5 entries instead of top 15, so I complied my own list manually linked here (https://github.com/gjusticea/forecast-tools/blob/master/NYT%20Best%20Sellers/Nonfiction%20Lists%20Raw.csv). I didn't find it super helpful in the end though, there's not enough books that sell for 9-18 weeks, most are either shorter are longer. If someone else can make use of this then do let me know. This forecast is fairly simple, I took a linreg of the book's position over time to get its forecasted level for the next 4 lists, calculated the z-score of a 15th place entry compared to forecasted value with SD calculated from the line's residuals. Converted each z-score to a p-value, then calculated the chance of none of them happening. In this model, for a rank of 15 or higher, June 20 has a probability of 14%, June 27 8%, July 4 4%, and July 11 2%. Chance of none of them is 74%.  I'm not sure how to factor in outside factors here, none seem very material. The chance of Adam publishing another great article and drawing attention is low since he hasn't published an article during the summer in a few years. Kahneman's new book may draw more attention to the genre and book since he endorsed Think Again, or may cannibalize its sales, hard to say. I'm just sticking to the outside view here.

Based on the analysis @LokiOdinevich and the confidence of @elifland, I'm going to up to up my estimate to the full value predicted by my analysis of 68% for the "Between 9 and 13" option.
Chart: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/think_again_rank/ThinkAgainRegPlot.png
Data: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/think_again_rank/ThinkAgainWeeks.csv
Code: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/think_again_rank/BestSellerWeeks.py
Reasoning: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1287355

Correction: 107+40 are submarines, of which 40 are also rollercoasters, so the chance of being a rollercoaster given that a book is a submarine is instead 40/(107+40): 27%. Adjusting downwards, this is 22%.

I downloaded a kaggle dataset of past NYT bestsellers (https://www.kaggle.com/dhruvildave/new-york-times-best-sellers), and calculated the chance on a book being a "submarine": going down and then back up again, and a "rollercoaster": going down, then back up again, then down, then back up again. Of 2320 titles, 107 are submarines, and 40 are rollercoasters. So the chance of a rollercoaster given a submarine is 37%. On the one hand, that 37% is for the whole lifetime on the book, on the other hand, I intuit that rollercoasters tend to happen closer to the initial run, so I'm adjusting this to 30%. My previous forecast, based on raw intuition, was 35%. My code can be found as a pull request to @JonathanMann's repository below: https://github.com/NunoSempere/gjopen/pull/1 https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1287355

Unless I'm mistaken, "More than 18" now impossible, so the only options left are "Between 9 and 13" and "Between 14 and 18". We're sitting at 13 weeks on the best seller list with 4 chances left. According to my modeling, Think Again is on a downward trajectory, but has a standard deviation of about 6 ranking spots. This means, to appear on the list next week, it would have to be about 1 standard deviation above my model's expectation. I estimate this to be about a 15% chance. If this does not happen it then has three remaining chances each with diminishing probability. When I calculated it out, it came to about a 68%, but I made a lot of assumptions that could be wrong, so I'll bias toward the crowd. 
Chart: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/think_again_rank/ThinkAgainRegPlot.png
Data: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/think_again_rank/ThinkAgainWeeks.csv
Code: https://github.com/jonathanmann/gjopen/blob/master/think_again_rank/BestSellerWeeks.py

HINDSIGHT update: This was a great rationale. And you were on the right side of maybe. Rerouting again. The base rate has been that Adam Grant's book is a zombie. His Amazon page for the book has come back from the dead as of writing, and the rankings in various Amazon departments such as Cognitive Psychology (Books), Popular Psychology Personality Study, Business Motivation & Self-Improvement have remained stable throughout its tenure on the NYT list. Additionally, Grant has a psychology PhD from Univesity of Michigan; they have summer courses coming up. Uni. of Stanford and Uni. of Berkley - the top 2 schools for psychology students - have summer courses coming up too. It's not unfathomable that hundreds of students in business, psychology, and the sorts buy his book for summer reading. https://www.amazon.com/Think-Again-Power-Knowing-What/dp/1984878107

With a return to list at #15 this week, it's now 13 weeks on with 5 weeks to go. What are the odds it makes the list at least on more time out of the next 5? (note: "more than 18" is an impossibility)

Increasing 2pp because of drastic drop to bottom of Top 100 books list on Amazon. Once it drops off, my assumption is that publicity will be greatly reduced because it no longer has that designation and exposure, obviously.

I need one more week to make my mind up more. It's time to start getting its affairs in order. Google Trends does not look pretty. 7 more chances until July 11. Nonetheless this book has been a strong outlier and exceeded expectations.

It's probably time to accept that the google trend data may work, ceteris paribus (all else being equal). Clearly, that's not the case- with a few heavy weight authors in the mix now - Michael Lewis, Gladwell; celebrities - Oprah, Bill O' Reilly, Seth Rogen, Billie Eilish etc.  Grant is very likely to end with 12 weeks- however, surprisingly enough, one additional week often turns into two additional weeks due to the autocorrelation, that we occasionally see in trends.

This calls for updating my priors. P(X < = 13) = 0.25,
P( 14 <= X <= 18) = 0.65,
P(X > 18) = 0.1

Oprah's and Gladwell's books are releasing on Apr 27- so we should see them in the next list.  Regardless, when I look at the trend data for Grant for this week, it drops by ~ 30%, yet I think, it's high enough for him to hang around, may be in the low teens or pre-teens.  I am not sure how predictive the time-series of trend data is, but it does seem that he's likely to get a seasonal tail wind for the following week ( I noticed a very similar pattern for the other books he had written). This seems to argue for the following distribution: P(X < = 13) = 0.5, 
P( 14 <= X <= 18) = 0.4, 
P(X > 18) = 0.1

https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1271521 and few other comments looked interesting so I mainly aligned on these to do this forecast. Moreover, bestsellers who last longer than 14 weeks don't look that rare (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_New_York_Times_Fiction_Best_Sellers_of_2020) so it seems plausible to me.

Two weeks as part of the rebound so far, but 9 is a fairly high rank to reach. My Own Words rebounded to 10-12-12 before dropping off again, and Killing Crazy Horse 12-13-14-14. Shade did 7-6-5-13, though that was also further away from its initial run so maybe less comparable.  I'm skewing further into the 14-18 bucket than I normally would because I'm wondering if the recent rebound is due to Adam publishing an article in the NY Times (on languishing) which was the second most popular article last week (https://www.nytimes.com/trending/ In Case You Missed It section) and that bringing more attention to the book. Most other non-fiction best-sellers are memoirs, books with political slants, or historical pieces, and most of the authors don't have the ability to grab the attention of a large groups of people who may not otherwise know who they are in the way that writing for NYT would do. Other books have definitely rebounded, but there's plausible reasons for at least some outside of just noise, like Shade and My Own Words rebounding after the election with court packing discussions and the Capitol riots.  If the article is why the current rebound is happening then I wouldn't expect it to last more than 1-2 more weeks tops, but it's reason to expect another one to occur in the future assuming any one of his next few articles between now and July 11 gain significant traction like the languishing one did. I still don't index into the higher bucket super heavily though. The current spike is on top of likely a high volume of people buying it because of "normal" reasons like word-of-mouth spread for a new release, so a similar spike may not lead to the book reaching a similar rank (i.e. the current spike lifted the book's rank to 9, but a spike of the same size may lift it to only 14 or 15 in the future if purchases for other reasons steadily decline between now and then). A future article published would need to gain a significant amount of traction, which is another if. The current run would also need to last another two weeks to have optimal chances of making it to 14 weeks off a future article, which is another big if if the languishing article was published 12 days ago and won't get the same amount of advertising by the NYT.  A few things need to fall into place in my current model of what's going on for the book to hit 14, but there's a plausible case to be made that it will happen. I also bump the 14-18 bucket a bit more in case I'm just misreading the whole situation.

11 weeks so far.  With continuous record I think 13 weeks is sure now. For whole time period only 3 weeks need to be missed to get to 18 weeks.  And there are only 7 weeks left to hit the 18 week threshold.  Given strong showing so far it’s more likely to be staying on the list especially as it’s slightly move up again this week.  So think it is now more likely to get to 18 weeks.

This one is surprisingly  harder than I initially gave credit for and after struggling for a bit- I decided to to list what I know
a) The book already spent 10 weeks on the list, so we can rule out the first couple of buckets.
b) Prof Grant is quite popular; looking at google trends relative to his competitors on the list for example, it seems to me that his "base level" of popularity is quite high and stable.
c) Looking at Amazon's best sellers where you can get a preview of coming attractions, I see a couple of of heavy weights- just round the corner - Oprah & Gladwell. Further, the following conclusions seem sensible to me d) It seems, generally speaking, one can stick around in this list for a long time, but one cannot climb back to a lost position. In other words, the direction of movement may be only one way- downwards. Physicists call this phenomenon entropy. At the time of writing this, Prof Grant is  #12. e)       (b) will help, but (c) will probably have a significant impact at least in the short term. In other words (c) + (d) makes the current bucket very likely, but not overwhelmingly likely.

New to forecasting and very unfamiliar with best seller lists (and didn't do much homework on it either). So a week into my forecast, and watching the book fall from #7 to off the list, it seems appropriate to rethink this one and dramatically change my forecast. With all the new books on the list this week, I won't be surprised to see Think Again back on the list, but my previous forecast now looks WAY too optimistic.
Quantitative model - assumes ranking next week will be mean 12 with 3 std dev. and mean increases by 0.25 each week - monte carlo with n=1000

It did dip off the list this week, but among books that lasted between 9-18 total weeks on the list (in my data since August of last year), 9 out of 10 dropped off at some point before coming back and getting more weeks. In my limited data set, four books lasted a total of 9-18 weeks dropped off later into their run, and after coming back accrued an additional 1, 3, 4, and 4 weeks. Others dipped off earlier, but that's likely similar to how Think Again sharply dipped to rank 10 early on. Think Again has been on for 9 weeks, so any of those 1-4 options would put it in the 9-13 bucket. However, if it comes back for 4, then all it would take is for it to reappear at rank 15 for a single week to put it over, a phenomenon which itself isn't uncommon.  9-13 is pretty likely, but the bouncing around in rankings just off the list add some uncertainty.
Unless there's a publicity stunt planned

Question here is around marketing and publicity. If say, Oprah, says to read it, boom we're back. If Adam is caught up in some sort of crime or scandal, boom, back baby. Best bet would be for an author to optimize their sales by sending an inappropriate text message to Oprah, just to be safe. Note: Bill Bryson's "The Body..." is back on the list. First thought was, "didn't that come out in 2019?" 
I can't find any reason why it is back on the list (outside of an active pandemic threatening the lives of millions.) 1) if anyone can find a reason why BB's "The Body" is back, I'd be interested in hearing your findings.
2) Somewhat related, anyone know the statistics around likelihood of a given title bouncing off and back on the list? How common is it?
3) Does Adam Grant have any publicity planned to speak of? Outside of podcast releases and the like...
I'm slightly late making this forecast, and it's had 9 weeks on the list. It has dropped off the list for 25 April so it seems unlikely to me it would return for another 4 weeks before the deadline.

According to the list as of 25 April 2021, Adam Grant has fallen off the list for the first time after appearing for 9 consecutive weeks, amid a host of new releases that have stormed to spots #1 through #6, among them the Hunter Biden biography. The maximum "Think again!" could achieve from now on would be 20 (?) weeks, excluding bins 1 & 2 already, but Adam Grant now has to compete with new releases every week for re-listing.

With it disappearing without warning, I am concerned it does not have the fuel to continue another 5 weeks of the remaining 11 or so to reach the next bin of 14–18. Though, I remain skeptical because its success in the past several weeks was above average on multiple points and this drop off the list could be just noise variance. But then again, what are the chances a book that hopped off the list makes a return and stays for another 5 weeks? Although I do not have the data nor the confidence to analyze such data, I do think that the odds are low. I have been anticipating that spring into summer would see newer book publications which would compete with the current list title holders. If Think Again does not make an encore next week, I will hone in my probabilities toward the current bin. Think Again's trending decline on Amazon books corroborates my forecast rationale.

I've finally been able to put together some data on this with the past 7 months of best seller data, since the NYT dev thing is difficult to use. First point is that it's pretty rare for a book to be on the list for 14-18 weeks. Since August 23, 22 books have been on the list at least once whose total number of weeks is >8 (and aren't on the current list). 8 have totaled 9-13 weeks, 12 have totaled 18+ weeks, but only two hit 14-18. Both of the books that hit 14-18 were from entries at rank 13-15, one for 1 week at rank 14 and one for 3 weeks at 15-13-15. The 9-13 books simply fell off the list at an average of rank 12. It seems like hitting the 14-18 bucket is mostly whether you luck into a couple extra lowest-rank weeks, which most books didn't do. The downward trajectory of Think Again is a bit too steep to justify a strong 18+ prediction, so a decent outside rate, admittedly based off of only 10 books, would be 80% 9-13 and 20% 14-18.  I temper that prediction a bit because Think Again has been performing above average compared to the 9-13 bucket, and has been slightly closer to the 14-18 one. Over their first 9 weeks, Think Again has been an average of 1.9 rankings above the average 9-13 book, and 1.2 below the average 14-18 book. It's been above the average 9-13 for 8/9 weeks, and above the average 14-18 in 5/9 weeks. These numbers are tiny, there's only 10 books to compare to, but this is just to say that the book's performance has been roughly mid-way between the two buckets, so an 80/20 prediction should be tempered a bit. Lastly, the sharp dip to #10 in week 3 for Think Again may mean something. Two other books had a sharp dip and then rebound like that, Humans and Blackout, and both lasted 9-13 weeks. All the books that lasted longer were more consistent over time, maybe due to more widespread advertising or word-of-mouth spread leading to more consistent sustained demand (or chance!). That only bumps the 9-13 bucket like 4-5%, it's only based on two other books, but something interesting to note nonetheless.
Adjusting long term a bit. Im surprised it lasted longer than 8, but still don't think it will beat 13. Hedging
9 weeks already and though it's past it's peak, it's not plummeting. 15 weeks sounds about right.

Looking at recent best seller trends, most books have a surprisingly bumpy ride along the top 15. Having a brief dip after a very high open appears pretty common, but a resurgence from lower on the list after isn't a common occurrence. The path will probably remain downward over time, but the degree of turbulence on that path is hard to say.
Already in it's 8th week on the list and still going up. There are also some strong contenders who are already on the list a long time.
It's having its ups and downs but I think it has some pretty good staying power. Eighteen weeks is where I believe it will drop off the list at the first of July.

Initial guess would be around 9-12 weeks for a non-fiction book that has been in the list for at least 8 weeks [1], looking at the occurrence counts for non-fiction books x weeks on the list. 
Considering that the book has had a maximum ranking of 1 (but fell soon), seems fair to update the estimate to something between the first and second rows of Figure 2 (D) [1], and then to restrict to the samples with at least 8 weeks listed. That seems to be dispersed mostly around 9-12 (row 2) or closer to 15-20 (row 1). Taking a middle ground (12-16) and subtracting 2 weeks, 10-14. Adding a bit of a long tail as books that are already long surviving seem to do well. I'll be a bit skeptical and note that search for the terms Think Again on Google Trends seems to be falling since release in February, though Grant is more stable.

I have no idea how to use the NYT API to pull historic best seller data, so charting typical paths on the best-seller list is not feasible for me unfortunately. The book's trajectory over time thus far is weirdly turbulent, which probably reflects the initial rush of people already familiar with the author and then the bandwagoners seeing it as a best seller that looks interesting, or people seeing the marketing materials like this forecasting question and then buying it.  There's a chance that the marketing and best seller hype dies down pretty quick and its only on for 8 weeks or less, but I'd imagine that the hype would take more time to percolate through the market than news would to his loyal followers. It did dip to #10 a couple weeks ago though and my narrative could be wrong, so I don't know.  9-13 seems the most reasonable for me. The author surprisingly doesn't have that many books published despite how well know he is, and Originals was only on the best seller list for 3 weeks (and Give and Take for 1) so 9-13 does fit a pattern of rapid growth that isn't super dramatic. The reception to the book seems positive but not on the level of like Thinking Fast and Slow or some Malcolm Gladwell book, so that'll be my main bucket.  Higher buckets are in case I'm wrong about the narrative, if the best seller hype lasts longer than I'm expecting, if the book randomly pops onto the list in the months after its consecutive streak ends, etc. The right data for this type of thing is hard to come across, so I'm leaving confidence levels fairly low.
It is more of an emotional reasoning, but because I think it should be up there for a while, I was optimistic.  Then just adjusted the different timelines accordingly.

My understanding of this list is shifting rapidly. Correct me if I am wrong, but consecutive weeks do not matter, correct? It is a total number of weeks even if there is a lull? That is a shifting working assumption for me. I'm just thinking out loud here but that means the comparison class we would need is books that have been published for the same period of time.... so if the range here is February 21st-July 11th that would mean that there are only 20 possible weeks to be used here. I will need to research an appropriate comparison but I think there is some off-the-top estimation that can be done.  So we can view it as will this be on the list either: <20% of weeks, 20-40% of weeks, 40-65% of weeks, 65-90% of weeks, or 90-100% of weeks. If you check the dates, we aren't even at 5 weeks, we are at 3. So thus far we are at 15% of weeks. Using that information, I'm going to bet the most likely outcome is the 40-65% scenario. #12 author female, famous/married to famous, topic autobiography, presidential history, "special" of broad interest, African-American contemporary history The categorization reveals:
the median case is 5.5 weeks at the moment, but the bandwith is extremely large from one new title this week to 99 weeks for the most successful book.
Female and male authors are exactly balanced in the number of titles, but female authors tend to be more succcessful with regards to a long listing appearance #2 (31weeks), #4 52 week, #12 (99 weeks), which may be correlated to female reading habits and  female readers being supposed to be more eager readers on average, spending more time and money on buying books & reading than average men, and may prefer slightly female topics, socioeconomic topics (gender equality, LGBTQ, social injustice, activism African-American present and history; which is kind of ironic, because the amount of conversation about activism usually > the amount of specific action and change) and obviously are more curious for autobiography (gossip?), individual career paths and topics of "special interest". The only specific male topic probably is 
WALK IN MY COMBAT BOOTS by James Patterson and Matt Eversmann with Chris Mooney ((4 weeks on the list) Rising high on the list, and staying there, usually pandered by either
/being reknowned and/or famous (Bill Gates, the Obamas)
/world-class achievements (Nobel-Prize laureates, award winning actors, Pulitzer prize winner), with an interesting life to depict
/having an urgent and/or global and/or "special" topic of broad interest that has a non-exclusive target group and is easy to identify yourself with or
/being billionaire (Bill Gates)
In the wake of the killing of George Floyd in 2020, the compound of African-American history, racial history, social injustice, women's rights and (Black) women who made it to the top, appears to be the topics with an extraordinary position among the bestsellers over the past 12 to 18 months; over the next 18 to 24 months, I predict the Bill Gates book ("How to avoid climate disaster") to have what it takes to become the next 100-weeks-blockbuster book, because of overlapping categories. It'll be a must-read.
It reveals as well that, for staying in the list for more than, say, 15 weeks, it requires to be special as an author, fame helps, but also a major achievement seems to be a reasonable indicator of a long appearance.
Adam Grant as an author is neither female nor African-American, nor actor, famous, Nobel laureate (not yet, at least), self-made billionaire entrepreneur (at least not publicly known for it), nor does the topic fulfill any of the requirements for an ultra-long appearance. The book that comes closest to Grant's own by topic is obviously 
#15 THINKING, FAST AND SLOW by Daniel Kahneman Farrar, Straus & Giroux (23 weeks on the list), but the main difference between the two authors is, both being part of the scientific community, the long career and the Nobel prize for Kahneman (lifetime achievements). The time for self helper/self-optimizer literature appears to be over, as in times of the pandemic, economic and climate crisis, other topics appear more imminent, and the merits of self-optimization are hard to earn in a lock down/home office business environment. However, his current standing (#3 in week 5), his track record as a bestselling author, and his well-established position in the small niche of his semi-scientific topic, and his contribution to popularize the topic, make it unlikely for "Think again!" to have 10 or less weeks of appearance only on the list.
Thus I expect "Think Again!" to remain on the list half of the time of Kahneman's book (currently 11.5 weeks) and then not return. This confirms my initial calculus in this post, and my previous forecast.  Note to myself: browse upcoming non-fiction bestsellers/recommendations for 2021, and date of publishing.

Right now it has been on the Combined Print & E-Book Nonfiction best seller list for four weeks, at #2, and has been rising. This list covers the top 15.  Comparison class: Thinking Fast and Slow, by Daniel Kahneman, has been on the list for 22 weeks as of today, despite having first been published in 2011. Holy cow!  So there is plenty of opportunity for persistence on this list. On the other hand, some books have brief stays on this list. Currently four books ave been on this list for three weeks or less. As a published author of nonfiction books myself, I know the mechanism whereby some books are only on this list briefly. If it still works the same way as when I last had reason to study it, the best seller list is biased toward new books that only reside there briefly because after a few weeks, if the book isn't selling well, distributors such as Amazon and other book sellers return unsold copies. These are subtracted from the total sold, causing a boom and bust effect. Right now, Grant's Think Again is on the cusp to the dread returns effect and thus could fall off the list with remarkable speed. On the third hand, days on the best seller count no matter how many days on not being there also might occur. So if sales figures fall off a cliff, they also could rebound as word of mouth gets around. Kahneman's Thinking Fast and Slow is an amazing example of longevity, and has much in common with Think Again. Both are well supported by research, well endnoted to academic standards, and both are easy, fun reads.  All that said, I was happily astonished by @crossonc 's use of base rate calculations on Adam Grant's previous books. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1237726 They also are consistent with my use of Kahneman's book as a base rate. So I am using the combination of both forms of base rate calculations for my forecast.

Looking at the distribution of # of weeks on list for the most recent 3 lists (Feb 21, Feb 28, March 7), it is heavily skewed towards lower numbers. About 1/3 of the books on the list each week are brand new, with only about 1/2 of them making it to a second week. The churn rate is pretty high. About 1/3 of books on the list have been on there for upwards of 14 weeks (and still counting!), but they would represent a small fraction of the number of new books that have come and gone (~4-5 books per week?), definitely below 10% overall but higher when you take into account only the population of books that have made it at least 3 weeks.

Maximum is 20 weeks in this time frame. Total books on the list is 15 books. Books get on the list not only by total book sales in the previous week, but also by discretionary approval by the NYT.  "Publishers eagerly slap “New York Times Bestseller” stickers on each book that appears on the list’s 15 slots. A quarter of those, however, have only a cameo appearance, briefly grabbing a spot at the bottom of the list and dropping out after a single week. Only 37% have some staying power and spend more than four weeks on the best-seller list." "That’s because book sales, we discovered, follow a universal sales curve — there’s a single mathematical formula that captures the weekly sales of all books. And that sales curve has a prominent peak right after the release, meaning you sell the most copies during the first weeks after your book’s release. "

3 things have determined my forecast: 1) Average length of time Adam Grant's previous books spent on the NYT Best Sellers list over a similar timeframe (ie counting 20 weeks starting from approx 2 weeks after publication). For "Give and Take", "Originals" and "Option B" this was 1, 4 and 19 respectively. Average is 8 weeks. There are reasons to think that "Think Again" may do better than average as Adam Grant has a higher profile now & no. weeks on list has been increasing with each book. However, "Option B" was written in conjunction with Sheryl Sandberg and has HEAVILY skewed this average so think 8 weeks is a decent approximation here. 2) The average length of time books currently on the NYT list (07/03/2021) have spent on the list. The simple average here is ~10.5 weeks. However, if we divide the no. of weeks each book has spent on the list by the number of weeks since its publication, we get the "no. of weeks on NYT list per week released". The average no. weeks on NYT list per week released is 0.57. If we standardise this to a 20 week period (ie multiple the "no. of weeks on NYT list per week released" by 20), we can get the expected number of weeks any of these books will spend on the list in a 20 week period.  By doing this, we get the following distribution. Out of the 15 on the list, we expect:
- Fewer than 4: 2 (ie 13%)
- Between 4 and 8: 4 (ie 27%)
- Between 9 and 13: 3 (ie 20%)
- Between 14 and 18: 3 (ie 20%)
- More than 18: 3 (ie 20%) 3) "Think Again" has already been on the NYT list for 3 weeks (falling from 1st to 3rd to 10th). It's therefore extremely unlikely to be fewer than 4. However, the falling ranking cause me to adjust my estimates towards the 4-8 and 9-13 range.
